text: now it is 18 months since this
journalist was jailed in Azerbaijan her
name is Katia Ismayilova
she's an award-winning investigative
reporter and an outspoken critic of the
government renowned her expose days of
corruption at the hands of the country's
president she was sentenced to seven and
a half years in prison for embezzlement
and tax evasion but her supporters say
the trial was politically motivated and
accused the president of cracking down
on press freedoms well with me now is
Carrie Esme loofas lawyer Amal Clooney
thank you so much for being here with us
on today's global let's start with the
bare bones of this case how disturbing a
case is it in your view I think it's
extremely disturbing I mean she is
literally Khadijah is one of the most
competent and courageous investigative
reporters in her country she actually
had a program on radio she worked for
Radio Free Europe in Baku and it was
modeled on your own the BBC's HARDtalk
program where she interviewed people and
she also published print articles where
she focused a lot on exposing corruption
and in the course of doing that she
discovered that there was lots of
evidence of corruption by the President
of the country mr.
Iliev and his direct family and you know
she's been reporting on that for years
and everything that she's been saying
has now been confirmed recently in the
Panama papers but obviously the
government wasn't too comfortable with
what she was doing and that's how she's
now in prison simply for the crime is
telling a while and she was sentenced to
seven and a half years I mean you must
be overwhelmed with cases that people
want you to actually get involved in and
take why did this one particularly what
was it about it that led you to actually
take it so I've represented other
journalists in the course of the last
few years and in doing so I've read a
lot about cases around the world
involving journalists and this one
really moved me because on the one hand
I found her to be this really courageous
inspirational woman a young woman 39
years old you know working in a country
where she knew very well the
consequences of being a reporter one of
her colleagues was gunned down
it just outside his house while his
family were there that there's a lot of
self-censorship being exercised and she
wasn't willing to play along and so I
found her to be inspirational and also
the idea that a government as a by Jean
that's a member of the Council of Europe
that they could actually so blatantly
put a reporter behind bars because they
didn't want her to be able to tell the
truth made me really angry and I thought
something I could do to help her and yet
their president has been in Washington
speaking with the administration they
seem quite pleased in the progress that
that country is making when you see a
reaction like that in Washington what do
you make of it well I think it's it's
clear I mean the good news is that we
know diplomatic pressure can work on the
on the government because what we had
happened last month is 147 political
prisoners sorry 147 prisoners were
released of which just over a dozen were
political prisoners Khadija was
vindictively left off the list perhaps
because she's a bit too good at what she
does but the the release the pardons
happened on the 18th of March and less
than two weeks later you had President
Ali I've seen has with Obama and meeting
with Vice President Biden so I do think
that was a positive step I'm glad that
those who've been released are now out
of prison but she is today the most
high-profile political prisoner left in
the country and that you know that can't
be allowed to persist so we as her
lawyer I filed a case before the
European Court of Human Rights seeking
to uphold her rights under the European
Convention which I'll come back to in a
second but I mean your fame or profile
or however you want to describe it would
you say it is a help or a hindrance in
terms of the cases that you're involving
yourself with well in terms of the the
legal part of the case which is what
I've worked on so far as I said I mean
we just filed last month of 150 page
legal submission to the European Court
which involved you know reading the
Azzurri tax code and and and researching
legal arguments so the profile of the
lawyer is really irrelevant when you're
just sitting behind a desk for hours a
day highlighting it's intricate lighting
and a gurney media have attacked you for
for taking the case they described it
let me read what
describe they say it your pursuit of it
is in your path for fame I mean are you
getting used to people attacking you for
for for taking cases and I suppose the
subtext of what people are accusing you
is that in a sense it's about you could
it be actually I found those attacks
quite laughable in a way I should be
reassured that if a government wants to
find a way to attack me that's the worst
they can come up with what happened was
in the pro-government media as soon as I
announced that I had taken on the case I
mean this is the first interview I've
given about the case actually so if I
wanted Fame I would probably have been
here a lot earlier I'm doing what I
think is in my clients best interest but
the full attack was that I must be of
Armenian descent otherwise why else
would I take on a case against
Azerbaijan and that's obviously
ridiculous you know I've represented
various governments I've represented the
government of Cambodia in a case you
know and equally Armenia but that's
nothing to do with ethnicity and
ethnicity is irrelevant is the flipside
though perhaps about all of this that
because of your profile a case like this
and Azerbaijani journalist I mean is
making waves in London in Washington in
Brussels would it otherwise absolutely
my my recent trip to Washington well yes
actually we've had organizations all
over the world the EU the UK government
the US government State Department and
others the US ambassador to the UN and
the Council of Europe all of those
organizations as well as for instance
amnesty and free speech groups have all
criticized Khadija arrest at the time it
happened and and said that her
conviction was unjust what I'm trying to
do is you know on the one hand bring a
case on her behalf before the European
Court I met with the Azerbaijan
ambassador to the US while I was in
Washington last week and he said we will
respect my country will respect the
judgment of the court so you know that's
one possible way out for her but at the
same time there are diplomatic
initiatives that are underway in the US
there's a bill that's been introduced in
the US Congress seeking to impose
sanctions on Azerbaijani officials so
part of my role as her representative
since I have to speak for her while she
can't speak for herself is to make sure
that those diplomats are briefed on the
case and that I draw it
try and help them exercise a name you
say have you got involved in this
because this is an issue that is close
to your heart when you look around the
world at the moment if you look at the
Chinese the Russia Iran Middle East
Latin America and free speech I mean
it's the world going backwards do you
think I think it's definitely going
backwards I think that we're facing a
free-speech crisis in the world today
and it's extremely concerning so it's
not only I mean first of all NGOs like
Reporters Without Borders have actually
wanted to dis and they've said there's a
decline in free speech standards in
two-thirds of the countries around the
world and that affects cut every
continent in the world and we see
examples so you mentioned sort of the
usual suspects if you like we you know
we wouldn't be surprised to see a
dissident locked up perhaps in China or
in Russia but it's it's happening in
many other places as well in Turkey
you've had almost 2000 prosecutions for
people who've dared to insult president
Erdogan including through the use of
cartoons you had missed Turkey posted a
poem that she thought was funny and
faced prosecution for that you have the
same thing going on in Thailand where if
you make fun of the king's dog you can
go to prison and in malaysia cartoonists
to being a sentenced to for sedition to
many years in prison so it's terrifying
i think it's happening in many more
places than people realize and that's
why people have to speak up i can't have
you here and leave without asking about
american politics in the elections
because together with your husband
you've you've had fundraising events for
the clinton campaign i mean any
presidential election is fractures but
particularly this one how critical do
you think is the particular crossroads
that America is at come November I think
it is really critical perhaps more than
in many other elections that have
happened in the US for a very long time
I I mean when you listen to what the
leading candidate on the Republican side
has been saying about building walls
about excluding Mexicans and and saying
you know there has to be a complete
shutdown on all Muslims entering and if
you actually look at what he
specifically said in that now sort of
infamous speech by Muslims he said he
kept saying you know they
I only want you had you know they they
don't believe in our way of life they
don't they don't respect our system and
when he says they and you know you watch
the media coverage afterwards people I
think should have been saying do you
mean the the 1.5 billion people around
the world who fit that description do
you mean the people who are US citizens
who are members of your military who are
you know the vast majority of whom are
not extremists or violence
anyways comments about Muslims not just
Muslims you know his comments about
women and yet Donald Trump is performing
extraordinarily well yeah in these
elections what do you think that says
then about America in 2016 I have to say
I'm probably as perplexed as you are as
someone sort of viewing these things
yeah there's an ad on TV in the US where
they went through all the statements
that he'd made against women and you
watch that anything gosh you know surely
I mean he's has a really high negative
rating I don't think he's going to get
much of the women's vote as a result of
that and I think ultimately you know
we're still dealing with the primary
season and not the full election and so
if at the end of all of this he gets
beaten by the person who becomes the
first female president of the United
States and I think that would send a
very positive message from the
electorate back to him as to what they
really think of those points of view
changing their us value
